questions.question: According to the D.I.G.E.S.T. Framework, what is the primary objective of the 'D' (Detect & De-stress) phase before moving into active microbial clearing?
options: Eradicating pathogenic biofilms using high-dose proteolytic enzymes
Identifying systemic triggers and reducing the total allostatic load to improve healing capacity
Introducing high-potency multi-strain probiotics to crowd out pathogens
Strict adherence to a zero-fiber elemental diet to starve opportunistic bacteria
questions.explanation: The 'D' phase focuses on assessment and removing obstacles to healing (stress, poor sleep, inflammatory triggers) to ensure the body can handle the subsequent 'Inhibit' and 'Gut Repair' phases.

questions.question: In Clinical Triage, if a client presents with both SIBO and a severely compromised Migrating Motor Complex (MMC), why is the structural/motility issue prioritized over microbial clearing?
options: Microbial clearing is impossible without the use of pharmaceutical antibiotics
The MMC only functions when the microbiome is in a state of perfect balance
Addressing dysbiosis without fixing motility often leads to rapid relapse as bacteria migrate back into the small intestine
Motility issues are easier to fix and provide a quick 'win' for client compliance
questions.explanation: Lesson 2 emphasizes that structural and motility issues (the 'plumbing') must be addressed to prevent the 'stagnation' that allows microbial overgrowth to recur immediately after treatment.

questions.question: When implementing 'Precision Supplementation' for antimicrobials, which strategy is recommended to minimize Jarisch-Herxheimer (die-off) reactions?
options: Starting at the full therapeutic dose immediately to 'shock' the system
A 'Low and Slow' titration, starting at 25% of the target dose and increasing every 3-5 days
Administering antimicrobials only on an empty stomach with high-dose Vitamin C
Using only one single herb at a time for a minimum of six months
questions.explanation: Titration allows the liver and lymphatic system to process metabolic byproducts of dying microbes, reducing the systemic inflammatory response known as die-off.

questions.question: In the 'Advanced Dietary Layering' lesson, what is the 'Rule of 3' for reintroducing high-FODMAP or high-fiber foods?
options: Introduce 3 new foods every day for 3 weeks
Wait 3 hours after eating a new food to check for immediate anaphylaxis
Introduce one new food in a moderate portion, then wait 3 days to monitor for delayed IgG or symptomatic responses
Eat the new food 3 times a day for 3 days to 'force' the microbiome to adapt
questions.explanation: The 3-day window is critical because many gut-related sensitivities (non-IgE) are delayed, occurring 24-72 hours after ingestion.

questions.question: Which physiological marker is identified in Lesson 5 as the most reliable non-invasive 'gold standard' for tracking improvements in Vagal Tone?
options: Resting Heart Rate (RHR)
Heart Rate Variability (HRV)
Blood Pressure (BP)
Respiratory Rate at rest
questions.explanation: HRV measures the variation in time between each heartbeat; higher variability indicates a dominant parasympathetic (vagal) state, which is essential for digestive function.

questions.question: During the 'Establish' phase (Lesson 6), which probiotic yeast is specifically highlighted for its ability to increase Secretory IgA (sIgA) and protect the mucosal barrier?
options: Lactobacillus acidophilus
Bifidobacterium infantis
Saccharomyces boulardii
Bacillus coagulans
questions.explanation: Saccharomyces boulardii is a transient yeast that has been shown in clinical trials to significantly boost sIgA, the primary immune defense of the gut lining.

questions.question: A client has been on a protocol for 12 weeks with zero symptomatic improvement. According to 'Troubleshooting the Non-Responder,' what is the first 'Pivot Point' to investigate?
options: The client's lack of willpower and dietary 'cheating'
The presence of recalcitrant biofilms or underlying co-infections (e.g., Mold/CIRS or Lyme)
Increasing the dose of the current supplements by 200%
Switching to a different brand of the same probiotic
questions.explanation: Non-responders often have 'hidden' drivers such as protective biofilms that shield pathogens or systemic issues like mycotoxin illness that keep the immune system in a chronic inflammatory loop.

questions.question: What is the '90-minute rule' discussed in the Neuro-Digestive Integration lesson regarding the Migrating Motor Complex (MMC)?
options: It takes 90 minutes to digest a standard meal
The MMC 'cleansing wave' only initiates after approximately 90-120 minutes of fasting between meals
Clients should exercise for 90 minutes daily to stimulate bowel movements
Vagal nerve exercises must be performed for 90 minutes to be effective
questions.explanation: The MMC is the 'interdigestive' housekeeper of the small intestine. It is inhibited by snacking, requiring clear 3-4 hour windows (and the overnight fast) to function properly.

questions.question: In the 'Thrive' phase, what is the primary goal of 'Metabolic Flexibility' in the context of gut health?
options: The ability to eat only processed sugars without weight gain
The capacity of the microbiome to utilize a wide variety of substrates (fibers/polyphenols) without triggering symptoms
The ability to switch between a ketogenic and high-carb diet every 24 hours
The permanent removal of all supplements from the daily routine
questions.explanation: A resilient gut is one that is 'metabolically flexible,' meaning the microbial community is diverse enough to ferment various fibers and produce beneficial Short-Chain Fatty Acids (SCFAs) without causing bloat or distress.

questions.question: When using Berberine as part of a 'Precision Supplementation' plan for dysbiosis, what is the standard therapeutic dosage range often cited for clinical efficacy?
options: 50-100mg once daily
500mg, three times daily (1500mg total)
5000mg total per day in a single dose
Berberine should only be used topically
questions.explanation: Clinical studies on Berberine for metabolic and microbial health typically use a dosage of 500mg three times daily to maintain steady-state serum levels and local intestinal concentration.
